intro: Ophrys × breieri, commonly known as the bee orchid hybrid, is a fascinating plant belonging to the orchid family Orchidaceae. It is a naturally occurring hybrid between Ophrys apifera, the bee orchid, and Ophrys insectifera, the wasp orchid. This plant is characterized by its highly specialized floral morphology, featuring a labellum that mimics the appearance of a female bee to attract male bees for pollination. The plant typically grows in calcareous grasslands and woodland margins, preferring well-drained soils. Its botanical significance lies in its role as a model organism for studying plant-pollinator interactions and hybridization in orchids.
